newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rupee ends up in spot, RBI buys fwd dlrs.
newsitem.headline: Indian rupee ends up in spot, RBI buys fwd dlrs.

text.p: The Indian rupee ended Wednesday at 35.82/825, up from Tuesday's 35.83/84 after a day of dull, range-bound trade, dealers said.
They said the rupee traded on Wednesday at a high of 35.82 and a low of 35.835 with stray deals at 35.8375.
"It was a pretty dull day," said a dealer at a state-run bank. "The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) was not in the spot market, there was little demand and the rupee drifted up slowly through the day."
Dealers said excess dollar supply continued to put pressure on the rupee to appreciate.
The rupee has been buoyant against the US currency in recent months and only RBI dollar purchases have kept it from appreciating.
Dealers said the RBI bought May-delivery dollars outright in the forward market.
"But they (RBI) did not buy much," said a dealer. "They hit the market briefly in late afternoon buying at rates which work out to 35.86."
Dealers said forward premiums moved up in late trade, in response to RBI purchases but ended at Tuesday's closing levels.
The annualised premium for six-month dollars ended Wednesday at 4.4.41 percent, unchanged from Tuesday's close.
